label: 五大尊
本: Jewel in the Ashes: Buddha Relics and Power in Early Medieval Japan . Harvard University Asia Center . 2000
説明文: Godaison (J.) 五大尊, also referred to as 五大明王、五大忿怒、五部忿怒、Go daimyō, Go daifunnu, Gobu funnu. The 5 awesome deities in esoteric Buddhism who guard Buddhism and its patrons, such as sovereign and country; the focus of the 仁王経法 ninnōkyō hō and 五壇法 godan hō esoteric rites, they are typically given as follows: Fudō is the central figure, corresponding with 金剛波羅密菩薩 Kongō haramitsu bosatsu (= 転法輪菩薩 tenbōrin bosatsu) and the Buddha Dainichi, surrounded by 1) Gōzanze (east), corresponding with 金剛手菩薩 Kongōshu bosatsu (= Fugen bosatsu) and the Buddha Ashuku, 2) Gundari (south), corresponding with 金剛宝菩薩 Kongōhō bosatsu (= Kokūbō bosatsu), corresponding with the Buddha Hōshō  3) Daiitoku (west) corresponding with 金剛利菩薩 Kongōri bosatsu (= 文殊菩薩 Monju bosatsu) and the Buddha Amida, 4) Kongōyasha (sometimes 鳥枢沙摩 Ususama, north), corresponding with 金剛牙菩薩 Kongōge bosatsu (= 摧一切魔菩薩 Saiissaima bosatsu) and the Buddha Fukōju. The Ninnōkyō hō was first performed (on behalf of the government) by  Kai in 810, and thereafter was commonly practiced as a nation-protecting ritual. The godan hō was first performed at Hieizan in 961, and was first performed in the palace in 1065. Well-known images of the 5 awesome deities are kept in Tōji (9th c.) and Daikakuji (12th c.), and the tapestries of them in Tōji (12th c.) and Daigoji (Kamakura era).
